name: Dear gentlemen, I could need your guidance here (Pally build with some extra cheese for the Lord of Terror)
author: Freaky Grandma

posts.author: Freaky Grandma
posts.content:
EDIT: Might update this post in the future, for now I leave it more or less empty, as the responses below more or less speak for themselves.

Thanks to everyone who gave me advice. Each input is highly appreciated.

The discussion below hopefully will help others who are new to more serious building, too.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
This might be stupid, because I've never built a Pally so I don't know its sensible cut-off points, but one thought might be getting 12 levels of Monk, with at least 6 pre-epic (so you get free Knockdown and IKD). 9 levels also gives you free Improved Evasion, and 12 gives undispellable spell resistance of 10+class level). You'd also have +40% speed (in robes) and +2AC (at level 10). You could always swap to the romantically named "fister" against the undead, if you so choose.

Now, avoiding the xp penalty, you might consider sacrificing WS and EWS and going for 10 levels of CoT, which also has a nice synergy with Paladin anyway. It also attracts bonus feats every other level, like Fighter, so you wouldn't be feat-starved, and your saves would also be improved. This would leave you 18 levels of Pally.

On the feats themselves: I would think you'd also want at least Blind Fight and Improved Critical pre-epic, with Armor Skin and Epic Prowess in epic levels. I don't know whether Lord of Terror allows Devastating Critical or not (I know SoF does), but if so, that might be a path worth exploring. If not, dual-wielding those kamas might work.

Like I said, though, I could be spouting absolute bollocks here...

posts.author: Freaky Grandma
posts.content:
Thanks a lot, Stagmeister.
Thinking about your suggestions cannot hurt after all.
I never played a lawful stup..., I mean: Pally type either, other than as part of a group in Icewind Dale and old SSI stuff. And unlike you, I never made a build worth mentioning.
Will get back to it later, have some other things to do this evening.

EDIT: Just did a quick check with that spreadsheet. Provided it was upgraded not too long ago, no builds with PAL and more than 3 MK levels exist so far (and now I wonder why that is...) so your suggestion still would be something new. Forgive me when I still would like to have more opinions.
(Should I end up using an already existing build, because nothing too different would work, so be it. My main purpose is learning. Should I, with your help, be able to play a new, unique build, that would be a great bonus, though. Does not have to be perfect, I just want to have a chance in the modules without too many tedious reloadings.)

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Hip's spreadsheet (or Fantabulous Contrapulator, as I prefer to call it) went "live" just over a year ago, so is pretty current, as there haven't been many new builds since, and the Legacy Archive is just that, so won't and can't have anything new added.

Knowing next to nothing about paladins (like you, the last time I used one was in Icewind Dale), I went and had a read of Max Kane's Guide to the class in the Game Guides sub-forum, which you might also want to give a once-over. What does strike me is that Expertise would be a nigh-essential feat to take, and Taunt (and probably Concentration) would be good skills. Another possibility might be to go for only a few levels of pally and lots more monkishness, but that's probably because Monk is my absolute favourite class.

You do right to await input from others, btw, because I could unintentionally be leading you down a blind alley here. But I do like the idea of a brand new type of build.

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content:
Let me just throw some ideas here, one at a time, slowly, so that we can have some interaction here & build this all together. How about instead of fighter we replace him with CoT instead? No Exp penalty then & instead of gaining ws/ews you gain divine wrath that synergizes very well with your potentially high charisma? You will also advance your saving throws that way, to the point you will be practically immune to anything that requires a saving throw unless you roll an "ace". Besides, ws/ews is not essential in a strength-build like yours, I do recommend building up some muscle though, just the base strength won't cut it.

Edit: Forgot to mention that "Lord of Terror" will start you at 3rd level if you go there with a 1st level character. Basically whenever you talk first time with an NPC in town, will give you 250 Exp so that when you are done talking to everyone you will have just enough Exp to make level 3, so take that into consideration.

posts.author: Freaky Grandma
posts.content:
Thanks a lot Valerfor!
I have seen some Pally/CoT builds here, with either Fighter or WM as third class.
I do not necessarily need WS and EWS, just got the idea from you mentioning it in the thread about Lord of Terror.
I will look up CoT and all the special features this Prestige Class gets in the wiki, then try again. Hopefully, will make this puzzle game a little easier, as I won't have to consider the XP penalty.
Good to know that I won't have to fight before 3rd level.
(Edit: Also good to know that I still can edit my first post so that the latest version of my future character always will appear in the first post)

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Hang on, I mentioned taking CoT rather than Fighter in my first post! I don't get much right, but when I do...

Anyway, I am now formally sulking and looking for small animals to kick (because the wall hurts a lot, believe me) 😡😉

posts.author: Freaky Grandma
posts.content:
Stagmeister wrote: Hang on, I mentioned taking CoT rather than Fighter in my first post! I don't get much right, but when I do...

Anyway, I am now formally sulking and looking for small animals to kick (because the wall hurts a lot, believe me) 😡😉
I was responding directly to Valerfor. I never meant to ignore your input. In an Edit in my first post I mentioned you both. In fact, I am looking into CoT now because two people said the same thing (I know that you were first), and when two experienced ECBlers agree about something, it can't be that wrong.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Worry not, my friend, I was merely having a (very) little fun. Believe me, like my head, my skin is thick!

Seriously, though, CoT is a great class (unless you're planning on being evil, which is not allowed). It's a full BAB fighter-type class, with few prerequisites. You need to have a BAB of +7, be non-evil, and have a weapon focus in a melee weapon (and Unarmed doesn't count). It receives a bonus feat every other level (like Fighter does) and has Fortitude and Reflex as primary saves. You will also get +1 to all 3 basic saves (Sacred Defense) on every other level (2, 4, 6, etc). And then there's Divine Wrath, which is CHA-based, and means for every 5 levels (starting at level 5) attack and damage and save bonuses increase by a further +2 (selected, short-term). CoT levels also stack with Pally levels for Smiting purposes (the only class that does). The only downside as opposed to Fighter is the lack of WS/EWS - although if you were to take it with Fighter up to level 4 (the first time you can get WS), you can take EWS as a CoT level. Oh, and you get Lay on Hands at level 1, and can take Great Smite and Great Wisdom in epic levels as bonus feats.

Hope this helps - though you might get more from the wiki.

Cheers

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:

How about instead of fighter we replace him with CoT instead? No Exp penalty then & instead of gaining ws/ews you gain divine wrath that synergizes very well with your potentially high charisma? You will also advance your saving throws that way, to the point you will be practically immune to anything that requires a saving throw unless you roll an "ace". Besides, ws/ews is not essential in a strength-build like yours, I do recommend building up some muscle though, just the base strength won't cut it.

Edit: Forgot to mention that "Lord of Terror" will start you at 3rd level if you go there with a 1st level character. Basically whenever you talk first time with an NPC in town, will give you 250 Exp so that when you are done talking to everyone you will have just enough Exp to make level 3, so take that into consideration.
Quick question, my friend, is Lord of Terror Dev Crit enabled? You didn't mention in your write-up.

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content:
Oh yes...If you have a very "stronk" character you could play a good portion of it with Dev Crit, which also makes it a perfect candidate for one of the empyre's rdd builds. Given the theme of the module though I would stick to the pally solution. Ahem...technically a pally/sorc/rdd is still both of these, but I am afraid we might be going too far-off here.

Edit: I am still laughing with the dodo in Scotland.

posts.author: Freaky Grandma
posts.content:
Problem with Dev Crit is, that I would need STR 25+...

Still puzzling.
I am not sure how many Monk levels to take. KD and IKD for free is nice, of course. As is Improved Evasion and the Spell Resistance. On the other hand, Monk has lower HP and BAB. Then again, more skill points...
I am also not sure when to take what. Both the Monk bonus feats and some feats I can only get as a Pally would be great to have as early as possible. Decisions, decisions...

Still on it. I also shouldn't forget that my main goal is learning. This includes patience (as it will take awhile until I have a playable character).

posts.author: Maximillian_Kane
posts.content:
Hey man!

Let me give you some advice in the form of questions. I know you've read my guide to the basics of building, so I'll use it as reference to guide your thinking process:

1- what is your character concept?
2- what do you want from each class? What is Paladin doing in the build? What is Fighter doing in the build? What is Monk doing in the build?

I already see a conceptual problem here. CoT and Fighter would, although appearing to be similar, complement the build in VERY DIFFERENT ways. Fighter would grant you more damage with EWS and one more feat than CoT, but would incur an XP penalty, which is a HUGE deal in finite XP settings (AKA non-PW play). CoT, on the other hand, would grant you a boost to saves and possibly extra Great Smite feats, if you decide to go down that road.

As I mentioned, you need to decide what each class is bringing to the build. You CAN'T use Kamas and get the Monk attack progression unless in Robes and no shield, and STR builds don't go well with robes. So, if you're taking Monk to wield Kamas, then DEX is the way to go. However, if Monk is there just for the feats and Evasion, then you really don't need that many levels.

If Pally is there for the buffs, then indispellability is desirable, and that's attained with 24 levels in the class. However, if it's there just for immunities and DM/DS, you don't need more than 4 levels of it.

If you want damage, then Fighter is the way to go for the 3rd class. If you want better saves and access to some of the divine feats, then CoT is better for that purpose.

Let me end this message by suggesting a few different spreads for you to toy with:

Pally 26 Monk 6 CoT 8 - full pally spellbook, indispellable, bonus feats from CoT and Monk. If made a STR build, better not to go for Kamas.

Monk 20 / Paladin 4 / Fighter 16

Could attack unarmed or with Kamas (Unarmed would likely do more damage) and be focused on DEX / CHA. You can trash Wisdom, and go Fighter 8 / Monk 8 / Pal 4.

Pal 17 / Monk 9 / CoT 14

This guy would have better saves, and 4 pally spell levels, but would be easily dispellable and Monk would only give Improved Evasion. This could be tricky, stat-wise, but that's the challenge with pallies anyway.

Also, you could read my guide on Paladins, to get a better understanding of the class and the diverse ways to use it in a build.

I didn't say it was going to be easy, but it's doable, with some thinking involved.

Cheers!

posts.author: Freaky Grandma
posts.content:
Thank you very much, Maximilian_Kane.
I will check the guide and your suggestions.
I am new to this way of building (do not ask how I "built" my characters in the past... I now see the reason why I never played hardcore difficulty), and I have to start *somewhere*.
So your fist suggestion would have high STR, but not so much CHA? And why exactly 26/6/8 levels and not, let's say, 24/6/10? I just want to understand (or maybe I can find it out somehow).
OK, going to do some reading and testing now.

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content: Let me answer that one right now, 26/6/8 & 24/6/10 has the same number of bonus feats but the first is better because it also gives you 2 more caster levels.

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content:
Also a suggestion for your first serious build FG,

DO NOT get overly complicated, start simple and stay effective, that's the key.

posts.author: Freaky Grandma
posts.content:
Ah, already thought that it might have to do with spells.
Yeah, I see why I shouldn't make it too complicated... ("first serious build", that's what it is). (Is is only me or was character building much easier with the old ADnD 2E, even when using extended rules?)
I wonder how to keep it as simple as possible, but still effective?
I'll check that 26/6/8 build in the Halls of Training to see myself what it does. For now, I give her the name "Goody Twoshoes". No kamas, but I still want high enough CHA to benefit from all that holy stuff.
I'll also look up some more Pally builds from here, to see what others did and how. (And why, that would be interesting, too.)

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
One thing you might consider with the 26/6/8 build is that in all likelihood you'll be taking your last level of Monk late (probably level 37) if you want to max the +8 AC from Tumble. Unfortunately, that means you won't be getting the free Knockdown twins until then. That was what first got me thinking about bumping up the levels of Monk and taking the first 6 pre-epic. Of course, you could take KD (and Imp KD, for that matter, but you'd need to ensure you have an INT of 13+, which you don't need for the Monk version) as a feat in its own right, but in that case you really don't need the 6 levels at all, and 3 or 4 would give you all the cheese you need.

If you're aiming for perfection at level 40, then all is well and good, but if you want playability throughout, it might be an issue. Again, as Max said, it depends largely on your concept.

posts.author: Freaky Grandma
posts.content:
Perfection at level 40? Won't help me when I can't survive the lower levels.
Playability from level 3 on is what is most important.
Found this here: divine-generalist-rogue-5-paladin-7-cha ... 43426.html
Uses Rogue instead of Monk to get Evasion, Tumble and Listen. Takes KD and IKD on CoT levels. Not exactly what I wanted, but has most of the feats I wanted pre-epic. Just a bit low on spells. (And somehow, WIS 8 looks a bit strange to me, as well as DEX 8 for a Rogue... )
Interesting how many different ways there are...
Off for awhile (I really do not feel like having cat food for dinner, so...), I will look around a bit more later.

posts.author: Empyre65
posts.content:
I put together a Paladin 18 / Monk 12 / CoT 10. I had to make some compromises because you can't have everything. Because you said you don't want complete builds, I won't post it, unless you ask me to.

I just thought of another idea: Paladin 20 / Monk 20, DEX-based and unarmed. That is 16 levels of Monk pre-epic for the d20 damage, and 4 more in epic levels for Tumble skill dumps. The main downside would be a low AB.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Empyre65 wrote: I put together a Paladin 18 / Monk 12 / CoT 10. I had to make some compromises because you can't have everything. Because you said you don't want complete builds, I won't post it, unless you ask me to.

I just thought of another idea: Paladin 20 / Monk 20, DEX-based and unarmed. That is 16 levels of Monk pre-epic for the d20 damage, and 4 more in epic levels for Tumble skill dumps. The main downside would be a low AB.
Can I ask you to post it, please? You could stick it in a spoiler with a "not to be opened by Freaky Grandma except in the case of dire curiosity" tag on it. I ask because I've been trying to have a go at that 18/12/10 split, but keep tying myself in knots (you know I still do it all with pencil and paper, and I'm afraid I've already used one tree's worth).

posts.author: Grimnir
posts.content:
Depends a bit on the setting. Taunt might help, and Pally buffs for sure. Especially Divine Favor. If you can rest a lot, or the mobs are manageable without heavy buffing, it might be okay. See what mileage you can get from it.

Sent fra min SM-G950F via Tapatalk

posts.author: Freaky Grandma
posts.content:
Thank you, Empire.

I don't mind you posting your build. No one says I will have to play that character exactly as he or she is. And when Stagmeister is curious about it, too, why not? Also gives me an opportunity to ask questions about the build to learn from it.
For me, most important is that I can learn something from this discussion here. While it would be great to play a build to which I contributed something, that is secondary. I have a lot yet to learn. There is so much to consider, and I always forget the half, lol... and many things I have to look up, especially when it is a class I haven't played yet.

posts.author: Empyre65
posts.content:
Here it is:
Spoiler Kama Knight 2 (Paladin 18 / Monk 12 / Champion of Torm 10) Playable 1 - 40 Abilities: DEX: 14 (15) WIS: 14 CHA: 14 (16) Leveling Guide: 01: Paladin(1): Power Attack, Blind Fight 03: Monk(2): Weapon Focus: Kama, {Deflect Arrows} 05: Paladin(3) 07: Monk(3) 09: Paladin(6): Two-Weapon Fighting 11: Champion of Torm(1) 13: Champion of Torm(2): Improved Two-Weapon Fighting 15: Champion of Torm(3): Toughness 17: Monk(7) 19: Paladin(8) 21: Champion of Torm(5): Great Strength I, (STR=19) 23: Champion of Torm(6): Epic Weapon Focus: Kama 25: Paladin(10) 27: Monk(10): Great Strength III, (STR=22) 29: Champion of Torm(8): Epic Prowess 31: Champion of Torm(10): Armor Skin 33: Paladin(12): Great Strength V, (STR=26) 35: Paladin(14) 37: Monk(12) 39: Paladin(17): Great Strength VI, (STR=27) Hitpoints: 456 Saving Throws (Fortitude/Will/Reflex): 35/29/32 BAB: 28 AC (naked/mundane armor/shield only): 26/32 Alignment Changes: 0 Skills: 02: Discipline(1), Tumble(5) 04: Concentration(1), Discipline(1), Taunt(2) 06: Concentration(1), Discipline(1), Save(1) 08: Concentration(1), Discipline(1), Taunt(1) 10: Concentration(3), Discipline(1), Tumble(1) 12: Concentration(2), Discipline(1), Tumble(4) 14: Concentration(2), Discipline(1), Save(4) 16: Discipline(1), Save(8) 18: Discipline(1), Taunt(6) 20: Concentration(3), Discipline(1), Tumble(1) 22: Concentration(1), Discipline(1), Tumble(4), Save(1) 24: Discipline(1), Taunt(5) 26: Discipline(1), Taunt(1), Save(1) 28: Discipline(1), Save(2) 30: Discipline(1), Save(6) 32: Concentration(5), Discipline(1), Tumble(5), Save(2) 34: Concentration(1), Discipline(1), Taunt(1) 36: Concentration(1), Discipline(1), Save(1) 38: Concentration(1), Discipline(1), Taunt(1) 40: Concentration(1), Discipline(1), Taunt(1)
Would you like me to make the Paladin / Monk 20, too?

You mentioned earlier that you used HipMaestro's spreadsheet to search for builds. Since you can use spreadsheets, you might find Kamiryn's Character Build Calculator useful.

posts.author: Maximillian_Kane
posts.content:
FG. If I may suggest something, have a look at the guide FIRST. That'll help you understand the main class of the build. Then, SECOND, have a look at a few existing builds and try to figure out the whys of each one. Why did he/she take so many/so few levels of the class. What synergies are there within the class combo?

I'll exemplify here: what are the synergies between CoT and Paladin?

Paladin has Divine Grace, adding CHA to saves, CoT gives save bonuses and even Monk synergizes here, having 3 strong saves.

Paladins who get Divine Shield and Might will be tight on feats, and CoT gives bonus feats to make up for that.

Monk and Pally also have some nice synergies. Pally casts from Wisdom, Monk uses Wisdom to add to AC and for Stunning Fists. Monk attack progression with Kamas and Pally buffs / Divine damage makes up for a REALLY HIGH DPR (Damage Per Round). But that only works on robes with no shield.

So you should try to get some kind of reasoning going before you sit down to make your own build. Once you understand the classes, then you can go back to the guide for the Basics to optimize the build.

I do have to say that Empyre and I are very different builders in style. He builds for playability, whereas I go for POWER! I have NEVER not been able to level any build, but I am a very experienced player, and I've been playing on World of Greyhawk (WoG), which is one of the most if not the most challenging environment out there, for over 10 years. My builds will generally be stronger, but harder to play. Empyre's builds will have a lot more playability, but be weaker at 40. Also, he builds for Single Player modules, which I never play. I build for PWs, where XP is infinite, and there's a big difference when you build for these settings. XP penalty is nothing more than a nuisance in PWs, but for Single Player modules, it can be a huge deal!

I'd also refer you to my "Playing Better" guide. Where I discuss in-game things that'll make you a better player.

Have fun!


Sent from my iPad using Tapatalk

posts.author: Freaky Grandma
posts.content:
@Empyre: With Open Office, I can open Hip's spreadsheet, but not the calculator. And when I use a test version of Excel, I can select classes, but nothing else. Would be really helpful indeed! Probably much easier than pen, paper and the Halls of Advanced Training.

Interesting build you have. Not what I had in mind (wanted Monk mostly for Evasion, gear, a few more skill points and a few points in Tumble and Listen), but might try it just for fun. A dual-wielding Pally, not what you see everyday. I like the idea.
Might I ask why you don't start with Monk? Would give 8 more skill points. Does it make any difference I am not aware of? Couldn't a first level Monk take the same feats?
Misread something in the wiki, by the way, which is why I got the idea of using a kama. Already wondered why the Monk extra attack still should work in full plate and with a tower shield, but yeah... in that case, it would have been really worth it.

@Maximilian Kane: Already read your guide about how to play better and had a look at the Pally guide.
I want to build better characters for single player modules mostly. They should be playable. So that I have a chance in hardcore and more fun. Not always at all levels (sometimes the first 2 or 3 or 15 can be ignored), but definitely long before level 40. Super powerful level 40 characters are nice, but skill dumps at level 37 don't help me much when I could need the skills (or extra feats) at levels 3-8 or so.
When I take something like this here: divine-generalist-rogue-5-paladin-7-cha ... 43426.html and go a bit into the direction you suggested in your comment to this build, this will be relatively close to what I had in mind at the beginning.

You guys are all so great!

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
Empyre65 wrote:I just thought of another idea: Paladin 20 / Monk 20, DEX-based and unarmed. That is 16 levels of Monk pre-epic for the d20 damage, and 4 more in epic levels for Tumble skill dumps. The main downside would be a low AB.
Funny that you came up with this class and level combo Empyre!
Earlier today I found an experimental build from 2015 with the same level split on my hard drive. The main idea was a stealthy paladin; a rare bird indeed. 🤓 🙃

The build is strength based: Str 16(30), Dex 14, Con 10, Wis 14, Int, 14, Cha 8. It has Greataxe as main weapon and a Pa 16/ M 4 level split at lvl 20. Unarmed only comes up as an alternative, but unfocused weapon late in the build. The character has AB +43 with the axe, AC 28 in robes, (with a possible AC 40 with capped Dex and Wis) and AC 29 in metal (without shield). Monk enables high speed in robes and full stealth ranks for surprise attacks.
No shield (two-hander) and Con 10 makes it a bit risky to play, even with toughness, taunt and expertise.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Ooh, all interesting stuff (he says as his pizza arrives it's a big one, so plenty for everyone).

If I might take this in an odd order:

@ Max: as ever, you encourage and bring people on. Sadly, very few have read your "Building Style x In-game Decisions" thread in the General Discussions sub-forum. I have, and others should. I'm only sorry I haven't got back to you again on it). I'm sure you would be the first to acknowledge - going back to your Aielund days - that things are very different in modules from how they are in PWs, and we're currently looking at SP modules.

@ Empyre: oh, that's clever, I like it - suitable hat-doffing, sir - just a shame we can't squeeze Listen or Spot in there. But I'm interested in why you went for kama rather than unarmed in a STR-build? I know the number of attacks increases because of the D-W, but you could swap that for a Dev Crit unarmed build (recognising you'd need a WF in a melee weapon for CoT). Should be do-able when you lose 3 feats (2 with that WF) and take Great Cleave, which then actually gives you one more feat for something else. Help me Obi-Wan Kenobi!

@ Freaky Grandma (btw, what can we call you for short? Freaky? Grandma? Strange childhood remembrances?) Ah, so you did only want Monk for the cheese, and Pally was your main goal. That's fair enough. Given Valeror's assertion that you won't have to commit to combat until after you hit level 3, Monk at level 1 shouldn't be a problem, except (iirc) you can't take Power Attack until you have a BAB of 1, which you wouldn't have, so you'd be doing some trading-off.

This is all good, innit? I know I'm enjoying it - and look, all the great and good (apart from Mick, who apparently is on a dodo hunt) are involved - and me, too! Good call Freaky Grandma!

EDIT: Bloody hell, Mick's here too, now! And, true to form, he's ninja'd me.

posts.author: Freaky Grandma
posts.content:
Call me what ever you wish. Granny or FG or what ever you see fit.
(This doesn't really belong here, but I AM a grandmother, albeit not by blood, just by marriage. I am not the oldest here, but old enough to remember a time without mobile phones. And sometimes I can be a bit crazy.)

Yes, Monk was for some extra cheese mostly.

I still want to try that dual-wielder one day. Ki damage is a nice thing, too. Have seen it from the "wrong" end. The dual-wielding monk probably would be much nastier when combined with something else, though. But that is not for now.

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content:
Let me throw another idea here, open for discussion of course.

What you need FG is not a full forty level build, but a thirty level one and your build ideally must be front-loaded as much as possible.

posts.author: Freaky Grandma
posts.content:
...unless I want to try SoF afterwards.
By "front-loaded" you mean melee I would assume.

posts.author: Empyre65
posts.content:
You have a point about getting more skill points if you take Monk at 1. I didn't think of that.  I was thinking about having 1 BAB at level 1, and about the NPCs identifying you as a Paladin. To the NPCs, you are whatever you took at level 1, even if you have 10 times as many levels in another class.

Before you start editing the spreadsheet, save-as into the native ods format. If it still won't work for you, I can email you an old version of the CBC that does work in Open Office, which is what I use.
wanted Monk mostly for Evasion, gear, a few more skill points and a few points in Tumble and Listen
Rogue would get you all those things, including gear via UMD, plus sneak attack.

By "front-loaded", he means getting as much of the good stuff as early as possible, in the front of the build. I generally try to do that because I build for single-player, which is what you are wanting at this time.

One more thing, the Paladin / Sorcerer / RDD idea would be a real hard-hitter, and the +4 AC from RDD would make up for having to cross-train Tumble (4 Tumble AC instead of 8).

@Stagmeister, if I went with unarmed instead of kamas, I would need at least 16 levels of Monk for the d20 damage, and then I would need more Monk than that, or else I would be forced to either get that d20 damage really late or get the last Tumble skill dump really early, which is what brought me to the Monk 20 / Paladin 20 idea.

posts.author: Freaky Grandma
posts.content:
I am grateful for any suggestions here, as I can only learn from them.
I will try to save the calculator as .odt and will contact you if this doesn't work.
Already realized that Rogue would get me all these things. Oh... yeah... I want the "good stuff" as early as possible, of course. All the live-saving feats and skills.
Haven't thought of Pally/Sorc/RDD yet, definitely will be worth some research.
(I still wonder what would be a good module to test that dual-wielder... I love DEX builds and dual-wielders, just wanted something else now. Like a lawful stupid char with stuff like DS, DM, Smite... and other things I haven't tried yet.)

EDIT:
Empyre65 wrote: and about the NPCs identifying you as a Paladin. To the NPCs, you are whatever you took at level 1, even if you have 10 times as many levels in another class.
Darn it, didn't know that. That is bad, indeed. If I start with Rogue, people will see me as Rogue. Meh... will have to re-think everything. Loads of RL stuff to do anyway (and I SOOOO do not feel like it), but I will return to this here later.
(Also got some stupid ideas, again, on how to challenge you guys here. With something not-so-serious that is not an actual build request, but a challenge for you expert guys just for the fun of it. Might make a post at the Tavern in the near future.)

As for the character, a level 30 build will get you through 99% of the modules out there since only three (Aielund, MTS & SoF) can reach higher levels.

I will prepare a level 30 character using your initial recommendation of classes and post it here later so that you can see what I am talking about.

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content:
SILVER FLAME OF ANDOR
 (PAL 17/ MNK 3/ COT 10)

RACE: Human
ALIGNMENT: Lawful Good
PLAYABILITY: PvM 1-30 level

STARTING/ ENDING STATS:
STR –  16 (22)
DEX –  08
CON – 12
INT –   10
WIS –  14
CHA – 15 (20)


Hit Points: 324

Skill Points: 105

Concentration: 9 (10)
Discipline: 33 (38)
Taunt: 33 (38)
Tumble: 30 (29)

Fortitude - (vs Spells): 31
Reflex - (vs Spells): 25
Will - (vs Spells): 25

Naked AC: 17 (Clothes)
Armoured AC: 28 (Full plate & Tower shield)

BAB: 24 (Four Attacks)
AB: +34/ +29/ +24/ +19 (Longsword)
DMG: 1d8 +6/ 17-20 x2 (Longsword)

Spellcasting: Paladin 4th Circle of spells
Smite Evil 3/Day: +5 AB, +27 Damage
Immunity to fear and disease, lay on hands: 135 hp's

Divine Wrath: +5 Attack Bonus, +5 Divine Damage, +5 Saving Throws, 5 Rounds Duration
Divine Might: +5 Divine Damage, 5 Rounds Duration
Divine Shield: +5 Dodge Armour Class, 5 Rounds Duration

LEVELING GUIDE:
1) Paladin (1): Power attack, Weapon Focus: Longsword
2) Paladin (2):
3) Paladin (3): Blind-Fighting
4) Paladin (4): {CHA+1}
5) Paladin (5):
6) Paladin (6): Divine Shield
7) Monk (1): Evasion, Cleave
8) Paladin (7):
9) Paladin (8): Divine Might, {CHA +1}
10) Champion of Torm (1):
11) Champion of Torm (2): Improved Critical: Longsword
12) Paladin (9): Extend Spell, {CHA +1}
13) Champion of Torm (3):
14) Champion of Torm (4): Knockdown
15) Paladin (10): Extra Turning
16) Paladin (11): {STR +1}
17) Monk (2):
18) Paladin (12): Extra Smiting
19) Paladin (13):
20) Champion of Torm (5): {STR +1}
21) Champion of Torm (6): Great Strength (1), EWF: Longsword
22) Paladin (14):
23) Paladin (15):
24) Champion of Torm (7): Great Strength (2), {CHA +1}
25) Champion of Torm (8): Armour Skin
26) Champion of Torm (9):
27) Monk (3): Great Strength (3)
28) Champion of Torm (10): Epic Prowess, {CHA +1}
29) Paladin (16):
30) Paladin (17): Great Strength (4)

NOTES: The single most important attribute for this build is "Charisma", it affects your saving throws (although they are already good), your divine shield & might's duration and damage, your divine wrath's duration, your "Taunt" skill, the number of "Turn Undead" you have at your disposal and finally your "Lay on Hands" healing capacity. Should you max it out (+12) you shall get a net (+6) to everything and (162) more hp's for your "Lay on Hands". You are also capable of casting the full repertoire of Paladin's incantations that are amongst the most potent in the game, giving you the ability to raise your total attack bonus by a significant degree, chief amongst them being "Divine Favour" a short (10 rounds duration) spell that raises both your attack and damage. That is why this build has "Extend Spell" amongst its feats so that you can populate your second level slots with extended versions of that spell. At lower levels pay attention to another 1st level spell that you have, "Bless Weapon" will simply annihilate undead struck by your sword. You also have a total of (14) uses of "Turn Undead" that can be used for Divine Shield and Might.

This build is front-loaded in order to get the most important feats early, but extended it to the full forty levels is something simple, should you want it.

Sent from my iPad using Tapatalk

posts.author: Freaky Grandma
posts.content:
Maximillian_Kane wrote: Ok, see you back in a year. I imagine you'll come out of this endeavor much like Tom Hanks came out of Cast Away.

Oh, that's a little exaggerated. Half a year should be enough.
😉
😆😆😆

OK, so with "Pia" (Bioware Legacy Divine Warrior) I am at the Poisoned Water Supply quest. Might need a hench or some supplies to battle the Miniboss here.
The three others just entered the Cathedral.
"Severin" (Kama Knight): is effective when it comes to fighting groups of weaker baddies. How he does against stronger enemies (and traps), we will see...
"Laurelia" (Silver Flame) has the advantage that she can carry a lot from the beginning. Did well so far.
"Tiberius" (Divine Generalist with a few tweaks) can get hurt a bit, but so did "Pia". I am curious if he can handle some of the traps (got some skill points into Disable Trap and Set Trap).
Fun way to directly see the differences, and as there is no skill schedule for the Silver Flame and I tweaked the Divine Generalist, there also is some exercise.
Wish learning something always would be so entertaining.

I will report how it goes when I get there. Probably not today, as I have a life and family.

posts.author: Freaky Grandma
posts.content:
Mick Dagger wrote: Your first real test will be against "The Butcher"!
Let us know how they fare against him.
The Divine Warrior Legacy build just soloed him. I have to admit that she had an unfair advantage, having gained 60K gold from shrines. Anyway, he wasn't as hard as I would have thought. Didn't even need to heal during battle...

With the others, I might have to save and reload a bit, as only the Kama Knight has enough cash to afford a haste item (the Divine Generalist might get and use a scroll, though).

EDIT: The Kama Knight needed to heal during battle, but also didn't have any problems (he is the second char who got lucky with shrines so that he is hasted and has nice gloves).
Needs healing against single strong Bosses, but when he is fighting groups, it is quite a sight... I want to keep him.

(will be continued later, might take awhile, though...)

posts.author: Freaky Grandma
posts.content:
Editing the other post didn't work properly, so I continue here:

The Divine Generalist still is a bit weaker in melee than the others, but for that, he has UMD and can set traps. Toughest was to finish the Poisoned Water quest, as I wanted to save potions, cash and my magic scrolls for the Butcher. A combination of setting traps, one smite and casting from scrolls did the trick here. (Good thing I had gotten some potions of Heal and a few Arcane scrolls with this character, they were much needed.)

The Silver Flame of Andor was low on money and potions, too, but I could afford a potion of Speed, at least. When facing the Butcher, she had two Paladin spell slots and still potion buffs, so he wasn't that much of a problem. Her smite does hurt a lot by now.

Will take awhile until I fight Big D. Maybe not with all four. In the meantime, I will check this forum daily to see what is going on. Don't wanna miss any fancy new stuff or greeting new people.

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content:
I would love to hear about your progress in "Lord of Terror" FG,

meanwhile here is a yardstick build suited to these kinds of modules, it is a front-loaded level 30 version of the "Puissant Paladin" and it could also go to Jordu's thread but I decided to put it here because of the theme of the module. For those that don't know about the original version, the theme is about a non-charismatic version of the classic paladin  that uses brute force & early dev critical for offense and his spells for defense (deathward, freedom of movement, protection from evil, etc). If you like more defense you could always take a tower shield & scimitar/ longsword setup.

This build's AB is so high that makes even weapon-masters weep (for reference my "Arelith Swordmaster" which is pretty optimized as a build, achieves a natural 40 AB by level 30) because it has a natural 37 AB which gets augmented by your awesome Paladin buffs by (8) more, then Taunt can rise it even higher by another (6), if you care to do that. And that's the "nice" Human version with plenty of skill points and an extra feat because the Half-Orc version (the original Puissant Paladin was a Half-Orc) gets both +1 AB and takes Dev Critical earlier, on his 23rd level. I could optimize this even more tbh but I wanted to show a yardstick build for level 30 and not the absolute maximum that it can achieve (which is not needed).

Puissant Paladin
(Paladin 30)

RACE: Human
ALIGNMENT: Lawful Good
PLAYABILITY: PvM 1-40 level

STARTING/ENDING STATS:
STR -  18 (26)
DEX -  08
CON - 10
INT -   14
WIS -  14
CHA - 08

Hit Points: 300

Skill Points: 165

Discipline: 33 (41)
Heal: 13 (15)
Persuade: 33 (32)
Spellcraft: 13 (15) cc
Taunt: 33 (46)
Tumble: 15 (14) cc

Saving Throws (Fort/Ref/Will): 17/ 10/ 13 (+3 Vs Spells)
Saving Throws (Fort/Ref/Will): 22/ 15/ 18 (Buffed Charisma)

Naked AC: 14/ 22 (Full Plate Armour)

BAB: 30 (Four Attacks)
AB: +37/ +32/ +27/ +22 (Greatsword)
DMG: 2d6 +12 / 17-20 x2 (Greatsword)

Devastating Critical DC: 33 (39)
Spellcasting: Paladin 4th Circle Of Spells (Undispellable)
Immunity to Fear & Disease

LEVELING GUIDE:
01) Paladin (01): Power Attack, Cleave
02) Paladin (02):
03) Paladin (03): Expertise
04) Paladin (04): {STR +1}
05) Paladin (05):
06) Paladin (06): Weapon Focus: Greatsword
07) Paladin (07):
08) Paladin (08): {STR +1}
09) Paladin (09): Improved Critical: Greatsword
10) Paladin (10):
11) Paladin (11):
12) Paladin (12): Knockdown, {STR +1}
13) Paladin (13):
14) Paladin (14):
15) Paladin (15): Blind Fighting
16) Paladin (16): {STR +1}
17) Paladin (17):
18) Paladin (18): Great Cleave
19) Paladin (19):
20) Paladin (20): {STR +1}
21) Paladin (21): Great Strength I
22) Paladin (22):
23) Paladin (23): Overwhelming Critical: Greatsword
24) Paladin (24): Devastating Critical: Greatsword, {STR +1}
25) Paladin (25):
26) Paladin (26): Epic Weapon Focus: Greatsword
27) Paladin (27): Armour Skin
28) Paladin (28): {STR +1}
29) Paladin (29): Epic Prowess
30) Paladin (30): Epic Skill Focus: Taunt

posts.author: Freaky Grandma
posts.content:
SoF I better play after something else. Where I end up not too far above level 25. I played through the whole thing with only one char. The last levels are a bit over the top. Fighting masses of OP monsters with OP equipment. The bonus levels got me from 29 to 35 (you might end up even higher when you do certain things in a particular order), and with the items I found I could open up a shop. Loved it, though.

Not sure what I will do next. Maybe try and see for myself how a dwarven wizard with a halberd can beat the OC or SoU and HotU on Very Difficult. Hard to believe when I read it.

Guess I will have to test all kinds of different builds. To see all kinds of different feats, skills and spells in action. (I still wouldn't know where to start was I to come up with a build of my own... wouldn't even know what character type to play where...)

Valerfor, why don't you post your level 30 builds in the mid-epic builds section? Would be easier to find for others.

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content:
FG I think you played the "cow level" as well, that's why you ended up so high level otherwise, you would end up between 28th and 30th level.

As for posting the build in the 30's sub-forum, I do not think it would be entirely appropriate because the other yardstick builds are in the "builds request" section as well. Now if I wanted to post the complete build in the 30's sub-forum then I would do so with its most powerful iteration which is a (Paladin 23/ Monk 1/ Fighter 6 OR Paladin 20/ Fighter 6/ Monk 4, for Arelith) and has everything this one has but also (+1 AB/ +6 DMG/ +3 AC & Evasion).

@ Grim I remember your "Knight of Yore" man & it was a powerful example of its kind. Myself, I prefer the (17/ 4/ 19) split however which is what I also use in my "Bonebreaker" builds with either Clerics or Paladins.

@ Stag, might I offer you a couple of halls for your cough? ;)

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Freaky Grandma wrote:
Stagmeister wrote: *cough* - Aielund - *cough*
I don't feel ready for that one yet. I wouldn't even know what character type to play...
Fair enough - although all sorts of characters will work (can't vouch for casters, I'm afraid) there. I've been a stealthy halfling, an AA, a DwD, a raging Barbarian, a dwarven archer, a Ranger, oh, and lots of Monks - including my first evil character, Mick's Kama Shinobi. If you haven't already, have a flick through the Aielund thread in the Modules forum - spoilers have been kept to a minimum.

If you fancy trying the build you've taken through LoT in a different environment, you could go through the OC and then Aribeth's Redemption (the character has to be Good; Human, Half-Elf or Elf; and male - so iirc you'd have to swap gender). I started a thread about it, again in the Modules forum. That should get you up to level 28-ish, so ideal for SoF.

Cheers.

Oh, and thanks for the offer, Valerfor, but a tot or two of the Macallan did the trick for the cough!
